awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Engineering Scalability of Durable Low-Noble-Metal-Content Fuel Cell Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be the demonstration of a commercially viable catalyst technology for hydrogen fuel cells. In the existing energy market, customer needs arise from the specific requirements of sustainable energy grids in terms of storage and conversion modules that manage the energy efficiency and meet stringent regulations for pollution. Hydrogen fuel cells have the potential to address most of those requirements. The potential commercial impact of the proposed project stems from increasing societal interest and market needs in clean energy and a sustainable environment. The technology will contribute to the replacement of fossil fuels and reduce emissions from stationary power plants and on-road/off-road transportation. The proposed technology development will benefit the manufacturers of fuel cell stacks or parts which currently suffer from high manufacturing costs associated with high-cost catalysts and short lifetimes of the catalyst in fuel cell operation. The technology also has the potential to benefit the agriculture drone manufacturers seeking an alternative lightweight, highly efficient energy package with long flight duration and low/zero pollution.  

This SBIR Phase I project will develop a new technology that enables hydrogen fuel cells with catalysts containing a low percentage of platinum group metals and a membrane electrode assembly with high activity and durability.  Key pain points in the fuel cell market are the high loading of platinum group metals in the catalysts and the poor durability of the current catalysts during operations. The goal is to develop a commercially viable route to the durable and low-platinum-content catalyst and membrane electrode assembly by nano-engineering the metal composition and synthesis scalability.  The proposed research and development will accomplish three major tasks including the development of a scalable synthesis route for the production of the targeted catalyst, the preparation of the membrane electrode assembly, and the evaluation of the performance in the hydrogen fuel cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
There is a growing need to transition away from fossil fuels as the primary energy source due to diminishing supply and rising greenhouse gas emissions. Among several alternative energy sources, hydrogen offers a clean and sustainable energy source which can be produced by water electrolysis using solar or wind energy. Hydrogen is utilized in hydrogen fuel cells to convert the chemical energy to electricity, which requires platinum as a catalyst. Platinum is, however, not only an extremely rare metal that drives the cost of a fuel cell to exorbitantly high cost, but also suffers from the propensity of poisoning that eventually leads to degradation of the fuel cell performance. This project focuses on translating a nanoscale alloy catalyst technology   to address the problems for the hydrogen fuel cell application.  The research develops a scalable manufacturing process that makes large quantities of low-cost catalysts and bring fuel cells closer to the market. The research demonstrates how platinum precursors can be combined with different earth-abundant metal precursors to produce the desired catalysts through controllable chemical reactions. Throughout this project many of these scalable catalysts were used for making membrane electrode assemblies and tested in hydrogen fuel cells of different sizes (up to 50 cm2), including prototypes for performance evaluations in different standardized testbeds.  The scalable low-cost catalyst-based fuel cell performance is compared to that using commercially available platinum catalysts, showing comparable performance with at least 50% reduction of the catalyst materials. The 200-hour durability tests demonstrated little or no observable loss in performance.  The reduction of the fuel cell cost and increase of their operational life bring us closer to a carbon neutral future and eliminate the use of fossil fuels. The project trained two graduate and two undergraduate students and two high school students.

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2024
Modified by: Dominic Caracciolo
